question: Yeah. This is great. I love this plan. Drag me kicking and screaming from my happy home in California to some weird place in Colorado, and say hey, this'll be fun Robbie. Maybe we can go camping....
answer: Look, I know you're not happy about this. But it wasn't my idea for your father to have some kind of mid-life crisis and disappear with his secretary to Mexico with our life savings.

question: "Administrative Assistant." There's no such thing as a secretary anymore.
answer: Fine. Administrative Assistant. We couldn't afford to sit around waiting any longer to see if he was coming back. I was able to land a good job here. And now thanks to Uncle Bernie you have this job at the Water Park...

question: Grounds crew. What kind of job is that? It sound like the guy who cleans out the coffee pots.
answer: Bernie says you help keep the park clean, sweep up, that sort of thing. I'm sure it won't be so bad. Besides, a lot of the kids who work at this park go to the same high school you'll be going to. You can start the school year with some ready-made friends.

question: I had friends in Oceanside. I had something to do for the summer.
answer: Hanging out at the beach surfing with your friends is not my idea of something

question: All thanks to Dad and his secretary.
answer: Administrative Assistant.

question: Whatever. Some summer....
answer: Promise me you'll give it a try....please?

question: Ohhh, hey Dougie. I'll catch up with you later... Hey, how you doin'? Haven't seen you before.
answer: I'm Robbie. Robbie Zirpollo.

question: I'm Alex. Where you workin'?
answer: I believe it's with the Grounds Crew?

question: What's the matter, can't swim?
answer: I can swim. Why?

question: Well, you look old enough to be a guard.
answer: Almost 16. I get my license in September.

question: It's just that most of the guys on grounds are a little younger than you. Most guys your age that can swim are guards.
answer: Well, I just moved here. I guess I missed guard tryouts. You're a guard then?

question: Oh, no no no. I work concessions...at Aokee's Surf and Snack Shack. It's just as well. The guards are mostly stuck up anyway. The rest of us are the ones who know how to have fun.
answer: Can't swim, huh?

question: Nope.
answer: What is that?

question: Surf tunes, dude! Ahh. And here we have the fair Melissa, time clerk extraordinaire... Dear Melissa. There's nothing about our relationship that couldn't be fixed by us spending a few moments together in the pumphouse behind Thunder Bay.
answer: Ouch.

question: My dear, you cut me to the quick. Check off my name and that of my amigo here, Mr. Robbie Zirpollo. She wants me. Yeeees?
answer: Whoa....who was that?

question: Eeeaasy there, big fella. Not in your lifetime. Or mine.
answer: So who is she?

question: Miss Tiffany Maxwell, daughter of Big Mike Maxwell, owner and operator of this here fine water park. See, Princess Tiffany and her friends pretty much have the run of the park. Her boyfriend is Dan Peterson, a guy we all call Cowboy, one of the lifeguards. Pretty decent guy from what I can tell. But she's a piece of work. Your best strategy is to steer clear of her and she won't cause you any trouble.
answer: Cowboy, huh. Big guy?

question: Big. Guy.
answer: Rob Zirpollo. Uh, Robert Zirpollo So what is this grounds thing, anyway?

question: Let's just say....you are critical and indispensable to the ongoing operation... and....flow of things here at the park. I'll show him. I'm going in that Left. Left. Left right left.
answer: David...how you do this to me? I have full staff with you. I save your spot. I was counting on you. Yes, yes....but The Gap? What you think you do there? Are there girls in swimming suits? Have you forgotten? Tips. Do you get tips? Cash money? Well, come see us this summer, eh? You're a good kid...a good worker. Yeah, you too.

question: Who....?
answer: David. Seems to think there is future in retail. Now what I do? I'm one person short. Park opens tomorrow.

question: You know...I just met a guy that's old
answer: Good guy?

question: Seemed like our kind of people.
answer: We need to get him before he get his plunger! Alex...... ..you got to go ahead... ...stall 'til I get there.

question: Well, it looks like we have a good staff here. Yes...yes a good staff. It will be an excellent summer. Remember as we go through training today, our park is judged by the work WE do. If we do it well, the people come back. We have a little tradition here on the grounds crew. Rather than having to learn a lot of names, many of which I can never hope to pronounce properly, each grounds crew member gets a grounds crew nickname. You will be known by that nickname in every way except, of course, your paycheck and employee records. Let's see, what do we have? Hmm...yes. OK, first up is Eddie Cochran. Your grounds crew nickname will be.....Eddie! Now crewmembers, listen up. Eddie here has eight years experience on the grounds crew. Why, I'd like to think there isn't anything, any situation that Eddie hasn't faced. Listen to him. Learn from him. Watch what he does. This man is the finest, most conscientious grounds crewman we've ever had. Let's see...Clark? Hmmm. Your grounds crew nickname will be....Sparky. Hmmm.....your grounds crew nickname will be.....Skeeter. Bradley, is it? OK, Mr. Bradley.....your grounds crew nickname will be Snitch. Melinda Tally. Hmmm... your grounds crew nickname will be...
answer: Hello, Colonel!

question: Alex, isn't it?
answer: Yes sir, Colonel. And what a fine staff you've assembled this year. Have you told them yet about your army background?

question: Well, no, I didn't think it was.. Well, it really wasn't much of a...
answer: Wasn't much? Can you just imagine for a moment the germs and bacteria our American soldiers could pick up in an unsanitised army latrine? It's impossible to determine just how many lives have been saved thanks to the efforts of this one humble Army Colonel.

question: Well, I suppose when you put it that way...
answer: I, too, came up through the ranks when at age 14, I began my service here at Water World learning from this great man.

question: Yes....I remember now.....what was your grounds nickname...?
answer: Not even sure I remember it myself, sir. But I remember much more. Did you tell them about the film?

question: Film?
answer: "Hygiene Makes You Happy" Every enlisted man in the army has seen it. Some by choice. All from the mind of The Colonel here...

question: Colonel....terrible mistake...
answer: Bureaucratic bumble...

question: Bureaucratic bumble....
answer: Lost paperwork....

question: Lost paperwork....
answer: An error in the front office...

question: Error in front office....
answer: Spiced applesauce....

question: Good God, man, what are you trying to say?
answer: It's Robbie sir. He was supposed to work at Aokee's and through some crazy mix-up, he ended up here.

question: Zirpollo? Well this is highly irregular... Most annoying....
answer: Never happened before....

question: Never happened before....
answer: Spaghetti marinara...

question: Sorry, Sarah, but I need to borrow this. Oh, Puh-leeaase. Ladies and Gentlemen, may I have your attention, please? In exactly 30 minutes, hundreds of dripping wet customers with fistfuls of money smelling of chlorine and suntan lotion will be walking in here. And what will they be looking for?
answer: The best teriyaki east of the pacific!!!

question: Annnnnnd?
answer: The finest smoothies in the state!!!

question: Now, everyone's a little tense, except me, of course. So to help you get in the proper frame of mind and relax, we need This is little tune I like to call the Paradise Slide. One, two, a one two three.
answer: Don Ho, Don Ho, Don Ho. Don Ho, Don Ho, Don Ho. Don Ho, Don Ho, Don Ho. Don Ho, Don Ho, Don Ho. Don Ho, Don Ho, Don Ho. Don Ho, Don Ho, Don Ho.

question: Right. See you in a little while.
answer: So that was a typical lunch crowd?

question: Well, it's early in the season yet. We'll get busier.
answer: Busier?

question: Don't worry. You'll get used to it. And tips were good, right?
answer: There's nothing like cash money in your pocket. What's that over there?

question: Oh, you'll find this ride interesting. It's a lot harder than it looks.
answer: I can't imagine it's that difficult. ...no rudder on the board...

question: Now this is a place of many wonders. See those guys in line over there? We call them "Wave Bums". They all have season passes, and do little more than ride the wave all day long. Some of them get pretty good. That's where they hang out when they're not riding the wave. Don't get too close to them.
answer: No?

question: Contact high. And there, my friend, is another one of The Wave's features. We call them "Wave Babes". And there's a special secret to this ride. Hey, Bob....can I borrow your radio a minute? Hey Frank, it's Alex. Listen you have a possible code 4. Means a "hottie". She's up next. A free chicken sandwich and a smoothie if you bounce up the pressure a bit. He knows my weak spot. Two Volcanos and a chicken sandwich. Watch, and wait.... Yesss!
answer: You were right. I was interested in

question: Well, sometime bring your swimsuit. We'll come back on break. I'll show you how to do it. Surf's is this way. And keep an eye out for Frank over there. We owe him. The First Aid station is over there. Just ask the guard. I just want to say hello to this girl I know.
answer: Hey. I've been sent to find some table stretchers and left-handed coffee pots.

question: Hey. I've been sent to find some table stretchers and left-handed coffee pots.
answer: Oh, you must be the new guy at Aokee's.

question: Yeah, how'd you know?
answer: Lucky guess. Saw some at the top of River Country. Just ask one of the guards over there.

question: Thanks.
answer: And hey...tell that wienie Alex he still owes me twenty bucks!

question: Alex!
answer: Jama...I mean...Jaffa the Jamaican...what shakes, it mon?

question: Jus' the same old this's and that's, mon.
answer: Jaffa, meet Robbie Zirpollo. Jaffa plays the tunes and talks the talk.

question: What? No way. (hangs up phone, to ALEX & Attention Lost River guards. We have a report that some huge fat bald guy has abandoned his swimsuit and is slidin' down Lost River with nothin' on but a smile. Be watchin' for a great white whale now. Attention please. Will Mr. John Big Bootay report to Lost River Splashdown. John Big-Bootay to Lost River Splashdown.
answer: He's calling for security.

question: Katie, this is Alex and...
answer: Robbie. Ummm, Rob Zirpollo.

question: Well, anyway, Big Mike's is where they are.
answer: Thanks.

question: What a couple of losers.
answer: I don't know...I thought Robbie was kind of cute...

question: Listen, you're new, so let me tell you how things are. First those guys were wearing blue shorts. That means
answer: Trash rats?

question: Bottom feeders. Grounds kids. Babies. They clean the toilets and empty the trash. Most are only 14 years old. It's the only job younger kids can do here. Next up is concessions. They're our "middle class". We don't hang with them and they don't much hang with us. At the top of heap are the guards. You are a guard. Girl, if you want to go out with someone, stick with your own kind.
answer: Aw, that's just silly. I think he's cute.

question: What did that girl Amy mean?
answer: About what?

question: When she said, when are you going to tell him?
answer: I'll tell you over a hamburger at Big Mike's.

question: Aokee's not going to be happy. Nobody seems to know where these things are...
answer: Yep.

question: What?
answer: There's no such thing as a table stretcher or a left-handed coffee pot.

question: What a dirty trick.
answer: It's just Aokee's way of giving you a tour of the park without having to be there. Consider it a rookie initiation.

question: Humph.
answer: Time to make it up to you. Come on. Hey Davey...how 'bout two for two? Chocolate. Now, if he ever shows up at our back door, we owe him chicken and smoothies.

question: But...don't we get an employee discount? Shouldn't we go in the front?
answer: Well...the discount is larger this way. Come on...let's go eat! Oh boy. Here we go.

question: What now?
answer: Aokee. The pigeons have been taking target practice on his trophy pedestal. Come on.

question: That stand is to display the coveted Surfer King trophy. Aokee seems to think that one day some concessions kid with more courage than brains is going to beat the lifeguards in the annual Employee Olympics.
answer: And what would this concessions kid have to do?

question: Nothing, really. Just out surf the strongest guard of them all in the surfing competition. No big deal.
answer: Has it ever happened?

question: So... you're not from around here, huh?
answer: California. I just moved here at the beginning of the summer.

question: I'll bet California's nice. I've never been west of the mountains.
answer: You'd love the ocean. And the sunsets are incredible. You can almost hear the sizzle as the sun drops into the ocean... Of course, we all know it doesn't drop into the ocean.

question: No. I'm surprised you're not a guard, coming from the ocean and all.
answer: Let's just say I missed my chance, and Alex saved me from a death worse than fate. I was very nearly a trash rat.

question: Well...how'd you do?
answer: Mmmm. I told her how beautiful the California sunsets are.

question: Good job. You work fast. Hey it's time for our break. Bring your swimsuit?
answer: Yeah. The Wave?

question: The Wave. I love that water. Can't swim. It's only three inches deep.
answer: Ah ha! Let's go.

question: Now, just take it easy, and don't expect too much at first. When you wipe out, your ride is done. Just ease into it. Gees. Where did you learn to do that?
answer: I'm from Oceanside, California. I was born on a surfboard.

question: Think you could ride that?
answer: In my sleep.

question: What you so happy about? Listen. Some guy came in today and try to buy a sandwich and pay with a phone card. Today I believe anything.
answer: I took Robbie to The Wave today.

question: What? He drown?
answer: No. It turns out that he's from Oceanside. California. You know, where they always hold those surf competitions?

question: Yeah. So?
answer: It turns out that he placed second in the state high school finals for the shortboard competition. As a Sophomore.

question: Robbie. Robbie barely walk without help.
answer: I saw it myself. You wouldn't believe it.

question: I don' believe it. Our Robbie?
answer: Our Robbie.

question: If this true....this could be da year.
answer: That's what I was thinking.

question: Well, go get him. We need to make ready. He not just walk in and win this thing.
answer: You heard it. He's in the kitchen...

question: Robbie, sit down. Alex, make up a Volcano. This boy in training.
answer: What did I spill now?

question: Robbie, Alex tell me you are some kind of surfer. This true?
answer: I dunno. Yeah, surfing is usually how I spend my summers.

question: You know about Employee Olympics?
answer: Yeah. Some kind of trophy.

question: Surfer King trophy. Very big. Very nice. Concessions never win.
answer: I dunno...seems kind of silly to me.

question: He very good. His family go to Hawaii every year, two, three weeks. Good surfer. If you do this, you need to see Pipeman.
answer: He's a myth.

question: Oh, no. Pipeman very real. Works here in park. Low profile. You must find him and convince him to teach you the secrets of the Thunder Bay wave. This not the ocean, surf boy.
answer: Pipeman. The Banzai Pipeline. I get it. Some kind of legendary surf champ. Where do we find him?

question: ....why you wouldn't believe the things I've heard. Just stupid things. Cutting in line. Demanding special treatment. Oh, and how about this one
answer: Oh, daddy. You know how jealous people get.

question: I'd almost believe that. But I was behind the First Aid station when you said the "princess" line. This park exists because the kids here work hard. They need to be treated fairly. They need to see you are just another lifeguard.
answer: But I'm not just another lifeguard.

question: You won't even be that if this continues. If you want to keep coming here every day and driving that little convertible of yours, I need to see real, concrete changes in your attitude.
answer: All right. What do you expect me to do?

question: For one thing, start mingling with "the commoners". You'd be amazed at how nice some of the people who work here are. Make some friends outside that little group of yours. It's the work of the average teenager here that puts food on our table. Show some gratitude.
answer: Fine. I'll work it.

question: Good. Work on it. Please?
answer: Oh, Daddy. Don't worry about a thing.

question: Sure. So. How are things working out at Aokee's?
answer: Oh, he's great. Alex too. I thought this summer was going to be a train wreck, but it's not turning out too bad.

question: Well, of course this isn't California...
answer: No, but it looks like I will get a chance to do some surfing anyway.

question: Really.
answer: Apparently there's some kind of surfing contest and Aokee is all over me to enter.

question: You mean the Surfer King?
answer: You've heard of it?

question: It's all the other girls seem to talk about. This is my first year, but
answer: We'll see. It seems kind of stupid to me. A surfing contest in Colorado.

question: Alex. Got my twenty bucks?
answer: Oh, Dougie. You know, I left my wallet over in my locker. I'll see you before we leave and get it to you then.

question: Yeah, sure.
answer: You know, you could always come by Aokee's and I could give it to you in trade.

question: Cash money, Alex. Cash money.
answer: No problem.

question: Hey, listen. Alex told me about this great spot on the other side of Thunder Bay that looks down on the party, but it's a little more quiet. Want to go for a walk?
answer: Sure. So...what made your folks pick up from beautiful southern California and move to Colorado?

question: Not both my folks. Just my Mom.
answer: Aha...trouble in paradise?

question: Let's just say my father had an eye for his administrative assistant, and now they're both somewhere in Mexico. Mom got a job here, some of her family's here, so they said "Colorady is the place you outta be".
answer: It could be worse.

question: Well, I must admit, I've met some very nice people. In California, the attitude's a little different. Here, not everyone is out to prove something. Seem's like everyone just wants to have fun.
answer: I have a theory. Sometimes it snows here so hard, that it's a challenge just to get to work or to school. Everything shuts down for a day or so. If your car gets stuck, people appear from nowhere to help pull you out and get you back on the road. Most people here don't just look out for themselves. A lot of times,

question: So where did you learn to dance like this?
answer: Eight years at Miss Vickie's Studio of Dance. What surprises me is you.

question: Can you keep my deepest, darkest secret?
answer: Of course.

question: When you grow up within spitting distance of Hollywood, every mother seems to think her child is the next Harrison Ford. So when I was about 12, my Mom started taking me to all these auditions for things.
answer: So are you the next Harrison Ford?

question: Some days I'm not even the next Robbie Zirpollo.

Turns out I get this part. They're selling some dish soap or something, and they think it will be magical to have two twelve year old kids dancing ballroom on this fantasy set with clouds and everything. They lock this girl and I into a dance studio with a choreographer for two weeks, and then they shoot the commercial.
answer: Doesn't sound so terrible. You certainly learned how to dance.

question: Yeah, but when it came out everyone in school saw it. I couldn't go anywhere for six months without everyone in the room laughing their heads off.
answer: I'm not laughing.

question: Hello? Hello?
answer: Hey. You're not supposed to be in here.

question: Yeah, sorry. Are you Pipeman?
answer: Not on purpose. I guess some people call me Pipeman. 'Spose it's better than Carl.

question: So you're real name's Carl?
answer: No. I just said Pipeman was a better name than Carl.

question: Oh. Well, my name's Robbie. I work at Aokee's.
answer: Oh. OK. What the hell you doin' down here?

question: I need your help.
answer: That scrubsink at Aokee's leakin' again? Gees, I knew we shoudda replaced...

question: It's not the scrub sink. I need your help. I'm competing in the Employee Olympics. With your advanced surfing experience, Aokee thought you might be able to help me.
answer: Everybody wants to be the Surfer King. What advanced surfing experience?

question: Well, you know. "Pipeman"? Hawaii's North Shore? Surfing the pipeline?
answer: Ohhh. Bad news, kid. I hate to disappoint you, but this is the reason they call me Pipeman. I'm the plumber around here.

question: Oh, boy. See, I'm from California, and I can surf, I just don't know what to expect from the wave on Thunder Bay. I...I was just hoping you could help, I really am sorry for bothering you.
answer: Wait a minute, kid. I do know a little about surfing. I also know a lot about the wave here. What exactly are you looking for from me?

question: I need a mentor; you know like in Karate Kid.
answer: Karate Kid. He works at Big Mike's doesn't he?

question: No, no it's a movie.
answer: Never seen it. Don't know much about this mentor thing. How's it work?

question: Generally, you, as mentor, draw on some personal religious philosophy to first intimidate, and then later inspire me. What religion are you?
answer: I'm Norman.

question: Ah, Brigham Young and all that.
answer: No, no NNNNORM-AN. We follow the big fat guy on Cheers reruns.

question: Okay...and your belief structure....
answer: Usually involves a lot of beer and corn nuts, but I don't think that's gonna work here. Tell you what. Meet me at Thunder Bay tomorrow morning,

question: Great, perfect. Thanks. I won't let you down. What the heck is a corn-nut? Hi! Glad you could make it. What's that?
answer: This is how I trigger the wave.

question: With that? A garage door clicker?
answer: What did you think? Waves just happen? This is Colorado, kid. Now get your board and get in the water. You sure that's where you want to be?

question: Should be about right. Aren't you getting in? Where's your board?
answer: Mentors don't get wet. I looked it up. Get ready. Want to know what you did wrong?

question: Just gimme another wave.
answer: Oakey doakey.

question: Okay. Please. Tell me what I did wrong.
answer: You're in the wrong position. The wave doesn't crest that soon. Move ten feet further away from the back wall.

question: So. I hear he's pretty good. Haven't seen him myself yet.
answer: Good? Good at what? Who you mean?

question: Come on. Your ringer from California. Everyone says he's gonna give Cowboy a run for his money.
answer: Robbie? Robbie barely walk without help.

question: Gees!
answer: Ha! Your Surfer King. We just make a good show. Your boy have nothing to worry about.

question: You know I'd feel a lot better if you hadn't taken most of my money in that poker game last Friday night.
answer: Poker? Not an island game. I no good.

question: Right. Tell you what. Sight unseen even money, twenty dollars on Cowboy.
answer: You want to bet with me? Take my twenty dollars, just like that? Humph. Not worth the trouble, twenty dollars. Now, maybe a hundred...

question: A hundred bucks...
answer: Robbie!

question: Sorry, dude, that tray was way off balance.
answer: Robbie, our secret getting out. You practice too good.

question: I'm really getting the hang of that wave.
answer: Fall more. Make good show.

question: I'll try to remember to look and see who's watching.
answer: Good. Here, have a smoothie. You too skinny to surf good.

question: OK, now this time, get up on the board more quickly. This is a wave pool and this wave dissipates quickly. You only have a little time to show your stuff.
answer: How will the judging work?

question: You get a possible ten points. Three for your surfing, three for your style and four for the judge's overall impression of your ride. No one's ever gotten a ten...I'm not really sure why.
answer: You've seen the competition. What does everybody do?

question: Everybody just surfs, man and tries not to fall. The big reason Cowboy's done so
answer: OK. I'm ready.

question: He's pretty good, I'll give him that.
answer: How good?

question: If I have an off day, he could win.
answer: That's terrible. You're the Surfer King.

question: Well, some days you get the wave, and some days the wave gets you.
answer: This can't happen. What are we gonna do?

question: I don't know what you're going to do, but as me for me, I'm gonna schedule some practice time of my own.
answer: This may take a lot more than extra practice.

question: Hey Jaffa. NO worries. People are betting on me?
answer: Just a little friendly pool. No big deal. Helps make this more interesting. Concessions never had a chance before...

question: I've seen this Cowboy practice. His style is more longboard, and this is a shortboard wave, but he's still pretty good. I could lose you know. How ya doin' See. How come everyone knows me by sight now?
answer: Ah, you're the next big thing. You'll survive it. The Employee Olympics are only a week away. What happens is we have this big opening ceremony where each team chooses a theme and we're judged on our spirit. Then different teams compete in contests that test their Water World skills. The next morning it all ends with the surf contest. You ready?

question: Yes, I'm sure you are. It's been a while since I've been to Aokee's. Do you suppose if I come down in a little while you could make some of that special chicken, what is it?
answer: The best teriyaki east of the Pacific.

question: Yes...and one those smoothies I hear so much about?
answer: Well, sure. I'll be working all afternoon.

question: Company! Forward, march. Company! Halt! Present Arms! Company!
answer: Yes sir.

question: Order arms. What do you do if it's wet and not yours?
answer: Don't touch it! Don't touch it!

question: How do you deal with a full can of trash?
answer: We empty! We empty!

question: Sound off!
answer: Trash Rats!

question: Again!
answer: Trash Rats!

question: Sound off, Trash Rats.
answer: Trash rats! Trash Rats!

question: Company! Brooms Ho! Company! Begin! What do you do when the table's a mess?
answer: We wipe it! We wipe it!

question: What do you do when a toilet's stopped up?
answer: We plunge it! We plunge it!

question: Sound off!
answer: Trash rats!

question: Sound off!
answer: Trash rats!

question: Sound off trash rats!
answer: Trash rats! Trash rats!

question: Hi Robbie.
answer: Oh. Hey.

question: How's your team doing?
answer: Uh. OK, I guess. Kind of a tie.

question: Well, I think you're going to take care of that tomorrow morning. In fact, I've planned a little celebration in advance. We're going to this incredible party up in the foothills at some friends of mine.
answer: Party, huh? That sounds like fun. I have to work until nine tonight.

question: I'm telling you we need to talk him. Something's going on.
answer: Robbie know the right thing to do. He's a good boy.

question: So how about this? He tells me I've got to cover for him if his mother calls. He told her he's spending the night at my house.
answer: He say that?

question: Yes. Tiffany's got something up her sleeve and Robbie's too messed up to
answer: Spending the night at your house. This very bad. Very bad. He should be done with the dishes by now. Tell him we want to talk.

question: Spending the night at your house. This very bad. Very bad. He should be done with the dishes by now. Tell him we want to talk.
answer: Hey. I'm done with the pots and pans. It's almost nine. Can I take off now?

question: Robbie, please, sit.
answer: Everything OK?

question: That's what we gonna ask you. What you plan tonight?
answer: Well, Tiffany invited me to a little party up in the mountains.

question: Robbie, you athlete. Big day tomorrow. You need sleep, not party.
answer: It's no big deal. I'll be fine.

question: Is big deal. Robbie. You good boy, smart, everybody like you, but....
answer: But...

question: Face it. Only one reason Tiffany interested in you. She want to make you so tired and so crazy you lose tomorrow.
answer: Aw, come on...

question: Aw, come on...
answer: Robbie. She's still going out with Cowboy. I saw them together at the movies two nights ago.

question: Maybe she's just letting him down easy.
answer: Robbie...things...things are not always what they seem to be.

question: My father refused to work for a drug lord who ran our town. They tried to kill
answer: Aokee?

question: A name I picked up reading an obituary in the paper. I sent away to Hawaii and got his birth records and social security number. This way, I never have to worry about immigration. I spent weeks watching tapes of Hawaii Five-O just to get the accent right. "Book 'em Danno". Huh. What's that all about?
answer: And you knew?

question: You think you can hold it?
answer: One time, these tourists from Japan on the beach at La Jolla offered me a hundred bucks to do a full spin at the top of the wave, and then slide down and cut back and do a full back flip. I pulled it off. A friend of mine had a tricks board with just a single fin and foot pockets.

question: We gotta pull the fin. What do we do about the foot pockets?
answer: You got duct tape?

question: What kind of plumber would I be if I didn't have duct tape? Water World
answer: Here and here.

question: I just want to thank Aokee, Alex and Katie for all their support. And I have just one thing to say to everyone in concessions. WE DID IT!
answer: Another summer gone. How about it Robbie? You gonna guard next year? They could use your help.

question: I don't know...we have a pretty good time at AOKEE's.
answer: You know, that's what I hear. Maybe I should work there next summer.
